Analyzing and Manipulating Ontologies¶

class ddot.Ontology.Ontology(hierarchy, mapping, hierarchy_attr=None, parent_child=False, add_root_name=None, propagate=False, verbose=True)[source]¶

A Python representation for constructing, analyzing, and manipulating ontologies.

This class’s attributes and methods are focused on the ontology’s hierarchical structure, i.e. a directed acyclic graph.

collapse_ontology(method='mhkramer', collapseRedundantNodes=None, verbose=True, default_relation='default', min_term_size=2)[source]¶

Remove redundant and empty terms. When a term T is removed, hierarchical relations are preserved by connecting every child of T with every parent of T. This removal operation has the nice property of being commutative, i.e. the order of removal does not matter.

Parameters:
  • method – If “mhkramer”, then use the collapseRedundantNodes script in the alignOntology package. If “python”, then use an internal Python script
  • propagate – If True, propagate annotations beforehand
  • min_term_size (int) – Remove terms that are below this size
copy()[source]¶

Create a deep copy of the Ontology object

delete_genes(genes_to_delete, inplace=False)[source]¶

Delete genes from ontology

ddot.Ontology.Ontology
get_annotation_matrix()[source]¶

Returns a gene-by-term matrix as a scipy.sparse.coo_matrix

get_best_ancestor_matrix(node_order=None, verbose=False)[source]¶

Compute common ancestor matrix.

lca[a,b] = index of least common ancestor of terms a and b

get_connectivity_matrix(sparse=False)[source]¶

Calculate which terms are descendants/ancestors of other terms

Parameters:
  • sparse (bool) – If True, return a scipy.sparse matrix. If False, return a NumPy array
  • a term-by-term matrix d where (Creates) –
Returns:

d – d[i,j] is 1 if term i is an ancestor of term j, and 0 otherwise. Note that d[i,i] == 1 and d[root,i] == 0, for every i.
Return type:

np.ndarray or scipy.sparse.matrix
get_connectivity_matrix_nodiag()[source]¶

Returns a similar matrix as in Ontology.get_connectivity_matrix(), but the diagonal of the matrix is 0.

Note: !!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
d[a, a] == 0 instead of 1
get_leaves(terms_list, children_list=None)[source]¶

Returns terms in <terms_list> that are not ancestors of any term in <children_list>

If <children_list> is None, then select the terms in <terms_list> that are not ancestors of any of the other terms in <terms_list>.

get_longest_paths()[source]¶

Computes the lengths of the longest directed paths between all pairs of terms.

Returns:NumPy array d where d[x,y] is length of the longest directed path from a descendant term x to an ancestral term y
Return type:np.ndarray
get_ontotype(gset_sample, prop, format='dict', dtype=<type 'numpy.int8'>, gene_ordering=None)[source]¶

Calculates the ontotypes of genotypes.

Parameters:
  • gset_sample (list) – List of gene sets (i.e. gsets) A “gset” is a set of genes, represented as a tuple
  • prop (str) – If ‘genes’, then the value of a term is the number of genes in the term which are deleted.
  • format (str) – The data format of the ontotype. Supported formats are ‘dict’, ‘scipy.coo’
Returns:

  • If format==’dict’, then return a list, where each element is a
  • dictionary representation of an ontotype.
  • If format==’scipy.coo’, then return a genotype-by-term matrix
  • as a scipy.sparse.coo_matrix
get_roots()[source]¶

Returns a list of the root term(s)

get_shortest_paths(sparse=False, chunk_size=500)[source]¶

Calculate the length of the shortest paths between all pairs of terms.

Parameters:
  • sparse – If True, return a scipy.sparse matrix. If False, return a NumPy array
  • chunk_size – Computational optimization: shortest paths are calculated in batches.
Returns:

d – d[x,y] is the length of the shortest directed path from a descendant term with index x to an ancestral term with index y. Term indices are defined by self.terms_index. d[x,y]=0 if no directed path exists.
Return type:

np.ndarray or scipy.sparse.matrix
get_term_sizes(propagate=False)[source]¶

Returns an array of term sizes in the same order as self.terms

get_tree_edges()[source]¶

Identify a spanning tree of the DAG (including genes as part of the DAG), and return a list of (u, v) edges in the tree.

is_dag()[source]¶

Return True if the Ontology is a valid directed acyclic graph, False otherwise.

propagate_ontotypes(ontotypes, prop, ontotype_size, max_ontotype, method='fixed_size')[source]¶

Propagates a list of base ontotypes.

Parameters:
  • ontotypes – An array of ontotypes in scipy.sparse.csr_matrix format. Each row is a separate ontotype.
  • method – If ‘fixed_size’, then the sum of values in every ontotype is exactly the same, namely <ontotype_size>
  • ontotype_size – If method==’fixed_size’, then this is the sum of values in every ontotype
rename(genes=None, terms=None, gene_prefix=None, term_prefix=None, inplace=False)[source]¶

Rename gene and/or term names.

Parameters:
  • genes (dict) – Dictionary mapping current gene names to new names. If specified, genes not in dictionary are deleted.
  • terms (dict) – Dictionary mapping current term names to new names. If specified, terms not in dictionary are deleted.
  • gene_prefix (str) – Prefix to append to every gene’s name
  • term_prefix (str) – Prefix to append to every term’s name
  • inplace (bool) – If True, then manipulate this Ontology. If False, create a new Ontology.
Returns:
Return type:

ddot.Ontology.Ontology

Runs the CLIXO algorithm and returns the result as an Ontology object.

Parameters:

  • alpha – CLIXO alpha parameter
  • beta – CLIXO beta parameter
  • min_dt – Minimum similarity score
  • timeout – Maximum time (in seconds) allowed to run CLIXO
Returns:
Return type:

ddot.Ontology.Ontology
semantic_similarity(genes_subset=None, term_sizes='subset', between_terms=False, output='Resnik')[source]¶

Computes the semantic similarity between pair of genes in <genes_subset>. Similarity s(g1,g2) is defined as \(-log_2(|T_sca| / |T_root|)\) where \(|T|\) is the number of genes in <genes_subset> that are under term T. \(T_sca\) is the “smallest common ancestor”, the common ancestral term with the smallest term size. \(T_root\) is the root term of the ontology.

Parameters:
  • genes_subset (iterable) – The set of genfes, over which pairs the similarity will be calculated. If <term_sizes>=’subset’, then term sizes will be recalculated according to only these genes, rather than all genes in the ontology
  • between_terms (bool) – if True, then output similarity between all terms
  • output (str) – type of semantic similarity
shuffle_genes(inplace=False)[source]¶

Shuffle the names of genes

summary()[source]¶

Returns a summary of the Ontology’s contents.

to_3col_table(output, header=False, parent_child=True, encoding=None, default_relation=u'default')[source]¶

Write Ontology to tab-delimited table with 3 columns and 2 types of rows:

Row Type A. Parent term, child term, ontology relation
e.g. “GO:0007005 GO:0007006 is_a”
Row Type B. Term, gene, “gene”
e.g. “GO:0007005 ATG7 gene”
Parameters:
  • output (str) – Filename of table
  • header (bool) – If True, include a header line in the table
  • parent_child (bool) – If False, then the first and second columns switch places
  • encoding – Character encoding
  • default_relation (str) – Relation type for all (child term, parent term) pairs. Note that the relation type for (gene, term) pairs is “gene”.
to_NdexGraph(name=None, description=None, term_2_uuid=None, represents=False, gene_attr=None, term_attr=None, gene_prefix='', term_prefix='')[source]¶

Formats an Ontology object into a NetworkX object with extra node attributes that are accessed by the hierarchical viewer.

  • spanning_tree (bool) – If True, then identify a spanning tree of the DAG. include an edge attribute “Is_Tree_Edge” that indicates
Returns:

igraph.Graph

  • spanning_tree (bool) – If True, then identify a spanning tree of the DAG. include an edge attribute “Is_Tree_Edge” that indicates
to_pandas(term_2_term=True, gene_2_term=True, default_relation=u'default')[source]¶

Convert Ontology to pandas.DataFrame

Parameters:
  • term_2_term (bool) – Include (child term, parent term) pairs
  • gene_2_term (bool) – Include (gene, term) pairs
  • default_relation (str) – The relation type assigned to all (child term, parent term) pairs
Returns:

Three columns: (1) Parent (2) Child – a gene or child term, (3) Relation type. The relation type of all (gene, term) pairs is “gene”.
Return type:

pandas.DataFrame
transitive_closure()[source]¶

Computes the transitive closure on (child term, parent term) relations. Transitivity rules are defined at

http://www.geneontology.org/page/ontology-relations

upload_subnets_ndex(sim, features, ndex_server, ndex_user, ndex_pass, name, gene_columns=['Gene1', 'Gene2'], propagate=True, public=False, gene_attr=None, verbose=False)[source]¶

Push subnetworks to NDEx

ddot.Ontology.align_hierarchies(hier1, hier2, iterations, threads, calculateFDRs=None, output=None)[source]¶

Align two hierarchies using alignOntology’s calculateFDRs script

Parameters:
  • hier1 (ddot.Ontology.Ontology) – First ontology
  • hier2 – Second ontology
  • iterations (int) – Number of randomized iterations
  • threads (int) – Number of CPU threads
  • calculateFDRs (str) – Filename of calculateFDRs script from alignOntology package. If None, then it is inferred based on ddot.config.
  • output – Filename to write alignment. If None, then don’t write.
ddot.Ontology.parse_gaf(gaf)[source]¶

Read gene-term annotations from GAF file format:

http://geneontology.org/page/go-annotation-file-gaf-format-21

Parameters:gaf (str) – Filename of GAF file
Returns:
Return type:A list of 2-tuples (gene, GO term)
ddot.Ontology.parse_obo(obo, output_file=None, id2name_file=None, id2namespace_file=None, alt_id_file=None)[source]¶

Parses an OBO file and writes the results into several tables.

Parameters:
  • obo (str) – Filename of OBO file
  • output_file (str) – Filename to write table that describes the ontology’s hierarchical structure. The table has four columns: (1) parent term, (2) child term, (3) relation type (e.g. “is_a” or “part_of”), (4) namespace of relation (e.g. “biological_process” or “cellular component”)
  • id2name_file (str) – Filename to write table of term descriptions. The table has two columns: (1) Ontology term (e.g. “GO:0000030”), (2) description (e.g. “mannosyltransferase activity”)
  • id2namespace_file (str) – Filename to write table of term namespaces. The table has two columns: (1) Ontology term (e.g. “GO:0000030”), (2) namespace of the term (e.g. “biological_process”)
  • alt_id_file (str) – Filename to write table of alternative Term IDs that are synonyms and refer to the same term. The table has two columns: (1) Primary Term ID, (2) Alternative Term ID
ddot.Ontology.read_alignment_file(f, source='Term_1')[source]¶

Parses an alignment file created from alignOntology’s calculateFDRs script

Parameters:
  • f (str) – Filename of alignment file
  • source (str) – Indicates which ontology will be the index of the returned pandas.DataFrame. Value must be either ‘Term_1’ (first ontology) or ‘Term_2’ (second ontology)
Returns:

DataFrame with four columns: ‘Term’, ‘Similarity’, ‘FDR’, and ‘Size’. The index of the DataFrame are the names of terms in the “source” ontology.
Return type:

pandas.DataFrame
ddot.Ontology.read_term_descriptions(description_table)[source]¶

Read mapping of GO term ID to their term descriptions

Parameters:description_table (str) – Filename of a tab-delimited table with two columns: GO term ID and term description
Returns:The index is the GO ID and the values are the term descriptions
Return type:pandas.Series
